title: 111_hr1956
content: The Act is titled the "Crime Victim Restitution and Court Fee Intercept Act" and allows for the offset of state judicial debts against income tax refunds. The "Crime Victim Restitution and Court Fee Intercept Act" amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow for the collection of past-due, legally enforceable State judicial debts through income tax refund offsets. The Secretary can reduce overpayment payable to a person by the amount of their State judicial debt and pay it to the State judicial branch or agency. The Secretary can reduce overpayment by the amount of a person's State judicial debt and pay it to the State agency. The notice must include the person's name, taxpayer identification number, address, and the reduced amount. If the offset is from a joint return, the notice must include information for each filer. The overpayment by a person can be reduced to pay off internal revenue tax liability, past-due support, or other debts as specified in subsections (a), (c), and (d) respectively. The overpayment can be used to pay off past-due support, federal agency debts, state income tax obligations, and covered unemployment compensation debt before being credited. The overpayment can be used to pay off past-due support, federal agency debts, state income tax obligations, and covered unemployment compensation debt before being credited. If the Secretary receives notice of multiple debts owed by the person to state agencies or the state judicial branch, the overpayment will be applied against those debts in the order they accrued. The overpayment will be applied to past-due support, federal agency debts, state income tax obligations, and covered unemployment compensation debt before being credited. For state agency or state judicial branch debts, the overpayment will be applied in the order they accrued. Rules similar to subsection (e)(4) will apply for debts under this subsection. A past-due, legally enforceable State judicial debt is defined as a debt resulting from a court judgment or sentence. State judicial debt is defined as a debt resulting from a court judgment or sentence in criminal or traffic cases, assessed as past-due but not collected. State judicial debt includes court costs, fees, fines, assessments, and restitution to crime victims resulting from a court judgment in criminal or traffic cases. The Secretary will issue regulations on the collection of past-due State judicial debt. The Secretary will issue regulations specifying how State judicial branches and agencies must submit notices of past-due State judicial debts, including necessary information and payment fees. The regulations may require State judicial branches and agencies to pay a fee to reimburse the Secretary for applying procedures. Any fee paid shall be used to reimburse appropriations that covered the cost. If an erroneous payment is made to a State judicial branch or agency, they must promptly pay back the Secretary. The State judicial branch or agency must promptly pay back the Secretary for any erroneous payments made, as required by regulations. Additionally, Section 6103(l)(10) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include disclosure of certain information to agencies requesting a reduction under specific sections. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include disclosure of certain information to agencies requesting a reduction under specific sections, with amendments made to sections 6402(a), 6402(d), and 6402(e) by inserting "(f), and (g)" in place of "(f)". Paragraph (3)(B) of section 6402(e) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to allow for the reduction of overpayments for State judicial debts before being credited towards future Federal tax liabilities. Similarly, paragraph (2)(B) of section 6402(f) is also amended in a similar manner. Paragraph (2)(B) of section 6402(f) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to allow for the reduction of overpayments for State judicial debts before being credited towards future Federal tax liabilities. Additionally, section 6402(h) is amended to include subsection (g) in addition to subsection (f) for overpayment reduction. The amendments made by this Act, pursuant to subsection (b), include changes to sections 6402(h) and 6402(j) of the Internal Revenue Code. These changes allow for the reduction of overpayments for State judicial debts before being credited towards future Federal tax liabilities. The effective date for these amendments is for refunds payable for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2008.
